00016 
00017 package WeBWorK::Utils::SortRecords;
00018 use base qw(Exporter);
00019 
00020 =head1 NAME
00021 
00022 WeBWorK::Utils::SortRecords - utilities for sorting database records.
00023 
00024 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00025 
00026  use WeBWorK::Utils::SortRecords qw/getSortsForClass/;
00027  
00028  # get a list of sorts
00029  my ($sortsRef, $sortLabelsRef) = getSortsForClass(ref $Users[0]);
00030  my @sorts      = @$sortsRef;      # sort names
00031  my %sortLabels = %$sortLabelsRef; # suitable for CGI's "-labels" parameter
00032 
00033  use WeBWorK::Utils::SortRecords qw/sortRecords/;
00034  
00035  # start with a list of records
00036  my @Users = $db->getUsers($db->listUsers);
00037  
00038  # sort the records using a preset
00039  @SortedUsers = sortRecords({preset=>"lnfn"}, @Users);
00040  
00041  # or provide a custom sort
00042  @SortedUsers = sortRecords({fields=>[qw/section student_id/]}, @Users);
00043 
00044 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00045 
00046 This module provides record sorting functions, and a collection of preset sorts
00047 for the standard WeBWorK record classes. Sorts are specified by a list
00048 of field names. Sorts are performed lexicographically.
00049 
00050 =cut
00051 
00052 use strict;
00053 use warnings;
00054 use Carp;
00055 
00056 our @EXPORT    = ();
00057 our @EXPORT_OK = qw(
00058     getSortsForClass
00059     sortRecords
00060 );
00061 
00062 use constant PRESET_SORTS => {
00063     "WeBWorK::DB::Record::User" => {
00064         "lnfn" => {
00065             name => "last name, first name",
00066             fields => [ qw/last_name first_name/ ],
00067         },
00068     },
00069 };
00070 
00071 =head1 FUNCTIONS
00072 
00073 =over
00074 
00075 =item getSortsForClass($class)
00076 
00077 Given the name of a record class, returns the preset sorts available for that
00078 class.
00079 
00080 The return value consists of a two-element list. The first element is a
00081 reference to a list of sort names. The second element is a reference to a hash
00082 mapping sort names to string descriptions.
00083 
00084 Together, these two lists are suitable for passing to the C<-values> and
00085 C<-labels> parameters of several CGI module methods, i.e. popup_menu(),
00086 scrolling_list(), checkbox_group(), and radio_group().
00087 
00088 =cut
00089 
00090 sub getSortsForClass {
00091     my ($class) = @_;
00092     
00093     my %class_presets = exists PRESET_SORTS->{$class} ? %{ PRESET_SORTS->{$class} } : ();
00094     
00095     my @field_order = $class->FIELDS;
00096     my @preset_order = sort { $class_presets{$a}{name} cmp $class_presets{$b}{name} } keys %class_presets;
00097     
00098     my %fields = map { $_ => "Field: $_" } @field_order;
00099     my %presets = map { $_ => "Preset: $class_presets{$_}{name}" } @preset_order;
00100     
00101     return ( [@field_order, @preset_order], {%fields, %presets} );
00102 }
00103 
00104 =item sortRecords(\%options, @Records)
00105 
00106 Given a sort specification (or the name of a preset format) and a list of
00107 records, returns a list of the same records in order according to the sort.
00108 
00109 %options can consist of either:
00110 
00111  preset => the name of a preset format listed by getFormatsForClass()
00112 
00113 or:
00114 
00115  fields => a reference to a list of fields in the records' class
00116 
00117 If C<preset> is given, and its value does not match any known preset but I<is>
00118 the name of a field in the record class, the records will be sorted by that
00119 field.
00120 
00121 If C<fields> is given, the records are sorted according to the specified fields.
00122 If multiple fields are specified, the second field is is consulted if two
00123 records are found to have identical first fields, and so on.
00124 
00125 =cut
00126 
00127 # DBFIXME sorting should happen in database (ORDER BY clause)
00128 # DBFIXME (but what about programmatic sorting, like intelligent setID sorting à la sortByName?)
00129 sub sortRecords {
00130     my ($options, @Records) = @_;
00131     
00132     # nothing to do
00133     return () unless @Records;
00134     
00135     # get class info (we assume that the records are all of the same type)
00136     my $class = ref $Records[0];
00137     my %class_fields = map { $_ => 1 } $class->FIELDS;
00138     
00139     my %options = %$options;
00140     
00141     if (exists $options{"preset"}) {
00142         my $preset = $options{preset};
00143         
00144         if (exists PRESET_SORTS->{$class} and exists PRESET_SORTS->{$class}->{$preset}) {
00145             # an explicit preset exists
00146             # replace the contents of %options with the values from the preset
00147             %options = %{ PRESET_SORTS->{$class}->{$preset} };
00148         } elsif (exists $class_fields{$preset}) {
00149             # it's the name of a field in the current class, in which case we treat it as
00150             # a "fields" sort with a single field
00151             %options = ( fields => [ $preset ] );
00152         } else {
00153             croak "preset \"$preset\" not found for class \"$class\"";
00154         }
00155     }
00156     
00157     if (exists $options{fields}) {
00158         my @fields = @{ $options{fields} };
00159         
00160         # test for existence of fields in class
00161         foreach my $field (@fields) {
00162             croak "field \"$field\" is not a field in class \"$class\"" unless exists $class_fields{$field};
00163         }
00164         my $pack_key = sub { join "\0", map { lc $_[0]->$_ } @fields };
00165         
00166         # use the Orcish Maneuver to pack_key only once per record
00167         keys my %or_cache = @Records; # set number of hash buckets
00168         
00169         return sort {
00170             ($or_cache{$a} ||= &$pack_key($a))
00171                 cmp
00172             ($or_cache{$b} ||= &$pack_key($b))
00173         } @Records;
00174     } else {
00175         croak "sort type missing from options. specify one of: preset, fields";
00176     }
00177 }
00178 
00179 =back
00180 
00181 =head1 BUGS
00182 
00183 No provision for case-insensitive, descending, or numeric sorting.
00184 
00185 No provision for programmatic sorts. While a one-time programmatic sort can be
00186 done easily without using this module, programmatic preset sorts would be
00187 useful, i.e. for intelligent sorting of set IDs.
00188 
00189 The fields being compared cannot contain nulls, because of the way packed keys
00190 are being generated.
00191 
00192 =cut
00193 
00194 1;
